[[Image:APPA LOGO.jpg|thumb|Logo of the African Petroleum Producers Association.]] [[image:African Petroleum Producers Association members, June 2009.svg|thumb|Map of states belonging to the APPA as of June 2009.]] '''African Petroleum Producers Association''', '''APPA''' (''Association des pays africains producteurs de pétrole'' in [[French language|French]], ''Associação de Produtores de Petróleo Africanos'' in [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] and ''رابطة منتجي النفط الأفريقية'' in [[Arabic language|Arabic]]) is an organisation of [[Africa]]n countries producing petroleum. It was founded in 1986. The headquarters of the organisation are in [[Brazzaville]] in the [[Republic of the Congo|Congo]]. The Organization has since changed its name to African Petroleum Producers Organization. Petroleum reform talk: APPA to APPO: https://www.vanguardngr.com/2017/07/petroleum-reform-talk-appa-appo The founding of APPA was spearheaded by [[Nigeria]] as an effort to mitigate the nation's dependency on Western technology and Western markets for oil export revenues. The objective of APPA was to promote cooperation in petrochemical research and technology. == Membership == The following African states are members of the African Petroleum Producers Association: {| class="wikitable sortable" |- !width="40" class="unsortable" | !! width="300"|State !! width="200"|Year of Entry !! width="80" class="unsortable" |Notes |- | {{flagicon|Algeria}} || [[Algeria]] || 1987 || APPA Bulletin 9, Page 22: http://www.appa.int/en/pub/Bulletin_APPA-n9_eng.pdf |- | {{flagicon|Angola}} || [[Angola]] || 1987 || |- | {{flagicon|Benin}} || [[Benin]] || 1987 || |- | {{flagicon|Cameroon}} || [[Cameroon]] || 1987 || |- | {{flagicon|Chad}} || [[Chad]] || 2005 || |- | {{flagicon|Republic of the Congo}} || [[Republic of the Congo|Congo, Republic of the]] || 1987 || |- | {{flagicon|Democratic Republic of the Congo}} || [[Democratic Republic of the Congo|Congo, Democratic Republic of the]] || 1989 || APPA Bulletin 9, Page 22: http://www.appa.int/en/pub/Bulletin_APPA-n9_eng.pdf
(Although not directly mentioned.) |- | {{flagicon|Côte d'Ivoire}} || [[Côte d'Ivoire]] || 1989 || |- | {{flagicon|Egypt}} || [[Egypt]] || 1989 || |- | {{flagicon|Equatorial Guinea}} || [[Equatorial Guinea]] || 1996 || |- | {{flagicon|Gabon}} || [[Gabon]] || 1987 || |- | {{flagicon|Ghana}} || [[Ghana]] || 2011 || APPA Bulletin 9, Page 22: http://www.appa.int/en/pmbres/ghana.html |- | {{flagicon|Libya}} || [[Libya]] || 1987 || |- | {{flagicon|Mauritania}} || [[Mauritania]] || 2008 || African Petroleum Producers Association website: http://www.appa.int/en/pmbres/pang.html |- | {{flagicon|Niger}} || [[Niger]] || 2012 || |- | {{flagicon|Nigeria}} || [[Nigeria]] || 1987 || |- | {{flagicon|South Africa}} || [[South Africa]] || 2005 || |- | {{flagicon|Sudan}} || [[Sudan]] || 2008 || |} ==Footnotes== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070613141917/http://www.appa.int/ APPA - official website] [[Category:International organizations of Africa]] [[Category:International energy organizations]] [[Category:Petroleum production]] [[Category:Intergovernmental organizations]] [[Category:Organisations based in the Republic of the Congo]]

'''Anne Daw''' is a [[South Australian]] campaigner for the protection of [[water resources]] and [[arable land]] from invasive [[mining]] activities.
Daw grew up on her father's grazing property near [[Kingston SE|Kingston]] in the state's South East region, and became the first community member to participate in the [[Government of South Australia|Government of South Australia's]] Roundtable for the ''Roadmap for Unconventional Gas Projects in South Australia''. She has also held a seat at the Round Table for Health and Energy Policy in [[Canberra]].<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.stockjournal.com.au/news/agriculture/general/news/shale-gas-risk-to-aquifers/2659792.aspx?storypage=1|title = Shale gas 'risk' to aquifers|last = Sutton|first = Malcolm|date = 2013-06-14|work = |access-date = 2015-03-07|newspaper = Stock Journal}}</ref> Daw has collaborated with the Environmental Defenders Office of South Australia, and formed the [[Limestone Coast]] Protection Alliance before going on to work independently <ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.edosa.org.au/woodcutters_road_video|title = Interview with Anne Daw|date = 2014-07-30|accessdate = 2015-03-07|website = Environmental Defenders Office of South Australia|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url = https://www.greenleft.org.au/node/53753|title = Unconventional Gas in South Australia — A Road to Nowhere|last = Waite|first = Robyn|date = 2013-04-08|work = |access-date = 2015-03-08|newspaper = Green Left Weekly}}</ref>
Daw began studying the development of unconventional and [[coal seam]] gas resources in 2007 and has since become a media spokesperson on the topics of [[groundwater contamination]] and risks to agricultural and rural community [[water supplies]] associated with [[fracking]].<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.abc.net.au/local/stories/2013/07/16/3803887.htm|title = To frack or not to frack?|last = |first = |date = 2013-07-19|work = ABC South East SA|access-date = 2015-04-09|publisher = ABC}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.adelaidenow.com.au/business/energy-minister-deals-blow-to-antifracking-campaign-in-sas-southeast/news-story/9fb20b0dd984202ad1804f6ed8b4561d|title=Blow to fracking campaign|access-date=2017-05-25}}</ref>
== References == <references />

'''Behenic acid''' (also '''docosanoic acid''') is a [[carboxylic acid]], the saturated [[fatty acid]] with formula C<sub>21</sub>H<sub>43</sub>COOH. In appearance, it consists of white to cream color crystals or powder with a melting point of 80 °C and boiling point of 306 °C.
==Sources== At 9%, it is a major component of [[Ben oil]] (or behen oil), which is extracted from the seeds of the [[Moringa oleifera|Ben-oil tree (''Moringa oleifera'')]]. It is so named from the [[Persian language|Persian]] [[Iranian calendar|month]] ''[[Bahman]]'', when the roots of this tree were harvested.<ref>http://www.numericana.com/answer/culture.htm</ref>
Behenic acid is also present in some other oils and oil-bearing plants, including [[rapeseed]] ([[canola]]) and [[peanut oil]] and skins. It is estimated that one ton of peanut skins contains {{convert|13|lb|kg}} of behenic acid.<ref name="lee">[http://www.hbci.com/~wenonah/new/pnutskin.htm USDA Scientists Find Treasure in Peanut Skins].</ref>
==Properties== As a dietary oil, behenic acid is poorly absorbed. In spite of its low bioavailability compared with [[oleic acid]], behenic acid is a [[cholesterol]]-raising saturated fatty acid in humans.<ref>Caterm, Nilo B and Margo A Denke. January 2001 [http://www.ajcn.org/cgi/content/abstract/73/1/41 Behenic acid is a cholesterol-raising saturated fatty acid in humans]. American Journal of Clinical Nutrition, v 73, No. 1, pp41-44.{{Verify credibility|date=July 2009}}.</ref>
== Uses == Commercially, behenic acid is often used to give [[hair conditioner]]s and [[moisturizer]]s their smoothing properties.<ref name="lee"/> It is also used in [[lubricating oil]]s, and as a solvent evaporation retarder in paint removers. Its amide is used as an anti-foaming agent in [[detergent]]s, [[Polishing|floor polishes]] and dripless [[candle]]s. Reduction of behenic acid yields [[behenyl alcohol]].
[[Pracaxi oil]] (from the seeds of ''[[Pentaclethra|Pentaclethra macroloba]]'') is a natural product with one of the highest concentrations of behenic acid, and is used in hair conditioners.
== See also == * [[Behenyl alcohol]] * [[Glyceryl behenate]] * [[Silver behenate]]

{{refimprove|date=August 2010}} A '''beltweigher''' or '''belt weigher''' is a piece of industrial [[control system|control equipment]] used to gauge the mass or flow rate of material travelling over a troughed (cupped) conveyor belt of any length which is able to adequately contain the material being weighed. These are also known as belt scales, dynamic scales, conveyor scales, and in-motion weighers. Many such [[check weigher]]s or [[feed weighers]] are an active part of the process flow control of the conveyor line.
A belt weigher replaces a short section of the support mechanism of the belt, which might be one or more sets of [[Idler-wheel|idler]] rollers, or a short section of channel or plate. This weighed support is mounted on [[load cell]]s, either pivoted, counterbalanced or not, or fully suspended. The mass measured by the load cells is [[integral|integrated]] with the belt speed to compute the mass of material moving on the belt, after allowing for the mass of the belt itself. Belt weighers generally include the necessary electronics to perform this calculation, often in the form of a small industrialized [[microprocessor]] system.
A belt weigher is normally mounted in a well supported straight section of belt, with no vertical or sideways curvature, and as close to level as is practicable. The weighed support must be aligned vertically and horizontally with the adjacent supports to avoid tensile forces in the belt skewing the measurement. Due the belt tension variation, frequent check calibration must be done.
Outputs from belt weighers are typically: * pulses at predefined increments of mass * an [[analog signal|analogue]] signal proportional to the flow rate
In addition, some belt weigher controllers will offer features such as driving an output to stop the belt when a predefined mass of material has been measured, or a range of alarms to indicate nil flow, belt slippage and belt stoppage.
Uses include mineral and aggregate extraction, continuous mixing processes, control of [[variable rate feeder]]s, port handling and ship loading processes.
== References ==
#[http://www.hkprocess.co.uk/belt-weighers.php Belt Weighers technical information available at HK Process] #[http://realtimegrp.kinja.com/why-you-should-go-for-a-belt-scale-otherwise-known-as-b-1778379221 Why You Should Go For A Belt Scale Otherwise Known As Belt Weigher?] [[Category:Industrial equipment]] [[Category:Weighing instruments]]

'''Bilayer graphene''' is a material consisting of two layers of [[graphene]]. One of the first reports of bilayer graphene was in the seminal 2004 ''[[Science (journal)|Science]]'' paper by [[Andre Geim|Geim]] and colleagues,<ref>{{cite journal |author1= Novoselov, K. S. |author2= Geim, A. K. |author3=Morozov, S. V. |author4= Jiang, D. |author5=Zhang, Y. |author6= Dubonos, S. V. |author7= Grigorieva, I. V. |author8=Firsov, A.A. |title= Electric Field Effect in Atomically Thin Carbon Film |year=2004 |journal= Science |volume=306 |issue=5696 |pages= 666–669 |arxiv= cond-mat/0410550 |bibcode = 2004Sci...306..666N |doi = 10.1126/science.1102896 |pmid=15499015}}</ref> in which they described devices "which contained just one, two, or three atomic layers"
== Structure ==
Bilayer graphene can exist in the AB, or Bernal-stacked form,<ref>{{cite journal|author1=K Yan |author2=H Peng |author3=Y Zhou |author4=H Li |author5=Z Liu |title= Formation of bilayer Bernal graphene: layer-by-layer epitaxy via chemical vapor deposition|journal=Nano Lett.|volume=11 |pages=1106–10|year=2011|doi=10.1021/nl104000b|bibcode = 2011NanoL..11.1106Y }}</ref> where half of the atoms lie directly over the center of a hexagon in the lower graphene sheet, and half of the atoms lie over an atom, or, less commonly, in the AA form, in which the layers are exactly aligned.<ref>{{cite journal|author1=Z Liu |author2=K Suenaga PJF Harris |author3=S Iijima |title= Open and closed edges of graphene layers |journal= Phys. Rev. Lett.|volume=102|pages=015501 |year=2009|doi=10.1103/physrevlett.102.015501|bibcode = 2009PhRvL.102a5501L }}</ref> In Bernal stacked graphene, twin boundaries are common; transitioning from AB to BA stacking.<ref name="nl204547v">{{cite journal |doi=10.1021/nl204547v |title=Twinning and Twisting of Tri- and Bilayer Graphene |year=2012 |last=Min |first=Lola |last2=Hovden |first2=Robert |last3=Huang |journal=Nano Letters |volume=12 |issue=3 |first3=Pinshane |last4=Wojcik |first4=Michal |last5=Muller |first5=David A. |last6=Park |first6=Jiwoong |pages=1609–1615|bibcode=2012NanoL..12.1609B |pmid=22329410}}</ref> Twisted layers, where one layer is rotated relative to the other, have also been observed.<ref name="nl204547v"/>
[[Quantum Monte Carlo]] methods have been used to calculate the binding energies of AA- and AB-stacked bilayer graphene, which are 11.5(9) and 17.7(9) meV per atom, respectively.<ref>{{cite journal|author= E. Mostaani, N. D. Drummond and V. I. Fal'ko|title= Quantum Monte Carlo Calculation of the Binding Energy of Bilayer Graphene |journal= Phys. Rev. Lett.|volume=115|pages=115501 |year=2015|doi=10.1103/PhysRevLett.115.115501|arxiv = 1506.08920 |bibcode = 2015PhRvL.115k5501M |pmid=26406840}}</ref> This is consistent with the observation that the AB-stacked structure is more stable than the AA-stacked structure.
== Synthesis ==
Bilayer graphene can be made by exfoliation from graphite <ref>{{cite journal|author1=Y Zhang |author2=T Tang |author3=C Girit |author4=Z Hao |author5=MC Martin |author6=A Zettl |author7=MF Crommie |author8=YR Shen |author9=F Wang |title= Direct observation of a widely tunable bandgap in bilayer graphene|journal=Nature |volume=459 |pages=820–23 |year=2009|bibcode = 2009Natur.459..820Z |doi = 10.1038/nature08105 |pmid=19516337}}</ref> or by [[chemical vapor deposition]] (CVD).<ref>{{cite journal|author= W Liu |title= Controllable and rapid synthesis of high-quality and large-area Bernal stacked bilayer graphene using chemical vapor deposition |journal= Chem. Mater.|volume=26|pages=907–15 |year=2014|display-authors=etal |doi=10.1021/cm4021854}}</ref> In 2016, [[Rodney S. Ruoff]] and colleagues showed that large single-crystal bilayer graphene could be produced by oxygen-activated chemical vapour deposition.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Y Hao |displayauthors=etal |title= Oxygen-activated growth and bandgap tunability of large single-crystal bilayer graphene |doi=10.1038/nnano.2015.322 |journal=Nature Nanotechnology |volume=11 |pages=820–23 |year=2016|bibcode = 2016NatNa..11..426H }}</ref> Later in the same year a Korean group reported the synthesis of wafer-scale single-crystal AB-stacked bilayer graphene <ref>{{cite journal |author1=VL Nguyen |displayauthors=etal |title= Wafer-Scale Single-Crystalline AB-Stacked Bilayer Graphene |doi= 10.1002/adma.201601760|journal= Adv. Mater. |year=2016}}</ref>
== Tunable bandgap ==
Like monolayer graphene, bilayer graphene has a zero bandgap and thus behaves like a semimetal. In 2007, researchers predicted that a bandgap could be introduced if an electric displacement field were applied to the two layers: a so-called tunable [[band gap]].<ref name="PRB75.155115">{{cite journal |doi=10.1103/PhysRevB.75.155115 |title=Ab initio theory of gate induced gaps in graphene bilayers |year=2007 |last=Min |first=Hongki |last2=Sahu |first2=Bhagawan |last3=Banerjee |first3=Sanjay |last4=MacDonald |first4=A. |journal=Physical Review B |volume=75 |issue=15|page=155115|arxiv = cond-mat/0612236 |bibcode = 2007PhRvB..75o5115M }}</ref> An experimental demonstration of a tunable bandgap in bilayer graphene came in 2009.<ref>{{cite journal|author1=Y Zhang |author2=T Tang |author3=C Girit |author4=Z Hao |author5=MC Martin |author6=A Zettl |author7=MF Crommie |author8=YR Shen |author9=F Wang |title= Direct observation of a widely tunable bandgap in bilayer graphene. |journal=Nature |volume=459 |pages=820–23 |year=2009|bibcode = 2009Natur.459..820Z |doi = 10.1038/nature08105 |pmid=19516337}}</ref> In 2015 researchers observed 1D ballistic electron conducting channels at bilayer graphene domain walls.<ref>{{cite journal|author= L Ju |title= Topological valley transport at bilayer graphene domain walls. |journal=Nature |volume=520|pages=650–55|year=2015|display-authors=etal|bibcode = 2015Natur.520..650J |doi = 10.1038/nature14364 }}</ref> Another group showed that the band gap of bilayer films on silicon carbide could be controlled by selectively adjusting the carrier concentration.<ref>{{cite journal|author1=T Ohta |title= Controlling the Electronic Structure of Bilayer Graphene|journal= Science |volume=313 |pages=951–954 |year=2006 |doi = 10.1126/science.1130681|bibcode = 2006Sci...313..951O }}</ref>
== Emergent complex states ==
In 2014 researchers described the emergence of complex electronic states in bilayer graphene, notably the fractional [[Anomalous quantum Hall effect|quantum Hall effect]] and showed that this could be tuned by an electric field.<ref>{{cite journal|author= A Kou | title=Electron-hole asymmetric integer and fractional quantum Hall effect in bilayer graphene |year=2014 |journal=Science|volume=345|issue=6192|pages=55–57|display-authors=etal|arxiv = 1312.7033 |bibcode = 2014Sci...345...55K |doi = 10.1126/science.1250270 |pmid=24994644}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|author= K Lee | title= Chemical potential and quantum Hall ferromagnetism in bilayer graphene |year=2014 |journal=Science|volume=345|issue=6192|pages= 58–61|display-authors=etal|arxiv = 1401.0659 |bibcode = 2014Sci...345...58L |doi = 10.1126/science.1251003 |pmid=24994645}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|author= P Maher | title=Tunable fractional quantum Hall phases in bilayer graphene |year=2014 |journal=Science|volume=345|issue=6192|pages=61–64|display-authors=etal|arxiv = 1403.2112 |bibcode = 2014Sci...345...61M |doi = 10.1126/science.1252875 }}</ref> In 2017 the observation of an even-denominator fractional quantum Hall state was reported in bilayer graphene.<ref>{{cite journal|author= Li J I A | title=Even denominator fractional quantum Hall states in bilayer graphene |year=2017|doi = 10.1126/science.aao2521|arxiv=1705.07846|bibcode=2017Sci...358..648L}}</ref>
== Excitonic Condensation ==
Bilayer graphene showed the potential to realize a [[Bose–Einstein condensate]] of [[exciton]]s.<ref name="PRL104.096802">{{Cite journal | last1 = Barlas | first1 = Y. | last2 = Côté | first2 = R. | last3 = Lambert | first3 = J. | last4 = MacDonald | first4 = A. H. | title = Anomalous Exciton Condensation in Graphene Bilayers | journal = Physical Review Letters | volume = 104 | issue = 9 | year = 2010 | doi = 10.1103/PhysRevLett.104.096802|arxiv = 0909.1502 |bibcode = 2010PhRvL.104i6802B | pmid=20367001 | page=096802}}</ref> [[Electron]]s and [[Electron hole|holes]] are [[fermions]], but when they form an exciton, they become [[bosons]], allowing Bose-Einstein condensation to occur. Exciton condensates in bilayer systems have been shown theoretically to carry a large [[Electric current|current]].<ref name="nphys1055">{{Cite journal | last1 = Su | first1 = J. J. | last2 = MacDonald | first2 = A. H. | doi = 10.1038/nphys1055 | title = How to make a bilayer exciton condensate flow | journal = Nature Physics | volume = 4 | issue = 10 | pages = 799–802 | year = 2008 | pmid = | pmc = |arxiv = 0801.3694 |bibcode = 2008NatPh...4..799S }}</ref>
== Superconductivity in twisted bilayer graphene== Pablo Jarillo-Herrero of [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology|MIT]] and colleagues from [[Harvard University|Harvard]] and the [[National Institute for Materials Science, Tsukuba, Japan]], have reported the discovery of [[superconductivity]] in bilayer graphene with a twist angle of 1.1° between the two layers. The discovery was announced in two papers published in [[Nature (journal)|Nature]] in March 2018.<ref>{{cite journal |doi= 10.1038/nature26160|author= Y Cao, V Fatemi, S Fang, K Watanabe, T Taniguchi, E Kaxiras, P Jarillo-Herrero |title= Direct observation of a widely tunable bandgap in bilayer graphene. |journal=Nature |year=2018|arxiv=1803.02342|bibcode=2018Natur.556...43C}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi= 10.1038/nature26154 |author= Y Cao, V Fatemi, A Demir,, S Fang, SL Tomarken, JY Luo, J D Sanchez-Yamagishi, K Watanabe, T Taniguchi, E Kaxiras, R C Ashoori, P Jarillo-Herrero |title= Correlated insulator behaviour at half-filling in magic-angle graphene superlattices. |journal=Nature|year=2018|arxiv=1802.00553|bibcode=2018Natur.556...80C}}</ref> The bilayer graphene was prepared from exfoliated monolayer graphene, with the second layer being manually rotated to a set angle with respect to the first layer. A Tc value of 1.7 K was observed with such specimens. Jarillo-Herrero has suggested that it may be possible to “...... imagine making a superconducting transistor out of graphene, which you can switch on and off, from superconducting to insulating. That opens many possibilities for quantum devices.”<ref>{{cite web |title=Graphene superlattices could be used for superconducting transistors|url=https://www.nextbigfuture.com/2018/03/graphene-superlattices-could-be-used-for-superconducting-transistors.html |publisher=[[The Next Big Future]] |accessdate=10 April 2018}}</ref>
== Field effect transistors ==
Bilayer graphene can be used to construct [[Field-effect transistor|field effect transistors]]<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Fiori|first=Gianluca|last2=Iannaccone|first2=Giuseppe|date=March 2009|title=On the Possibility of Tunable-Gap Bilayer Graphene FET|url=http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/4785198/|journal=IEEE Electron Device Letters|volume=30|issue=3|pages=261–264|doi=10.1109/led.2008.2010629|issn=0741-3106|via=|arxiv=0810.0128|bibcode=2009IEDL...30..261F}}</ref><ref name="NatureNano2010.89">{{Cite journal | last1 = Schwierz | first1 = F. | title = Graphene transistors | doi = 10.1038/nnano.2010.89 | journal = Nature Nanotechnology | volume = 5 | issue = 7 | pages = 487–496 | year = 2010 | pmid = 20512128| pmc = |bibcode = 2010NatNa...5..487S }}</ref> or tunneling field effect transistors,<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Fiori|first=Gianluca|last2=Iannaccone|first2=Giuseppe|date=October 2009|title=Ultralow-Voltage Bilayer Graphene Tunnel FET|url=http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/5233800/|journal=IEEE Electron Device Letters|volume=30|issue=10|pages=1096–1098|doi=10.1109/led.2009.2028248|issn=0741-3106|via=|arxiv=0906.1254|bibcode=2009IEDL...30.1096F}}</ref> exploiting the small energy gap. However, the energy gap is smaller than 250 meV and therefore requires the use of low operating voltage (< 250 mV), which is too small to obtain reasonable performance for a field effect transistor,<ref name=":0" /> but is very suited to the operation of tunnel field effect transistors, which according to theory from a paper in 2009 can operate with an operating voltage of only 100 mV.<ref name=":1" />
In 2016 researchers proposed the use of bilayer graphene to increase the output voltage of [[Tunnel field-effect transistor|tunnel transistors]] (TT). They operate at a lower operating voltage range (150 mV) than silicon transistors (500 mV). Bilayer graphene's energy band is unlike that of most semiconductors in that the electrons around the edges form a (high density) [[van Hove singularity]]. This supplies sufficient electrons to increase current flow across the energy barrier. Bilayer graphene transistors use "electrical" rather than "chemical" doping.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://newatlas.com/graphene-transistor-clock-speeds-100-ghz/43499|title=Ultra-low power graphene-based transistor could enable 100 GHz clock speeds|last=Irving|first=Michael|date=May 24, 2016|website=newatlas.com|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-04-30}}</ref>
== Ultrafast lithium diffusion ==
In 2017 an international group of researchers showed that bilayer graphene could act as a single-phase mixed conductor which exhibited Li diffusion faster than in graphite by an order of magnitude.<ref>{{cite journal |author= Kühne, M |title= Ultrafast lithium diffusion in bilayer graphene |journal= Nature Nanotechnology |volume=12 |pages= 895–900 |year=2017 |doi= 10.1038/nnano.2017.108|arxiv=1701.02399 |bibcode=2017NatNa..12..895K }}</ref> In combination with the fast electronic conduction of graphene sheets, this system offers both ionic and electronic conductivity within the same single-phase solid material. This has important implications for energy storage devices such as [[lithium ion batteries]].
== Ultrahard carbon from epitaxial bilayer graphene ==
Researchers from [[the City University of New York]] have shown that sheets of bilayer graphene on silicon carbide temporarily become harder than diamond upon impact with the tip of an [[atomic force microscope]].<ref>{{cite journal |author= Gao, Y |title= Ultrahard carbon film from epitaxial two-layer graphene |journal= Nature Nanotechnology |volume=13 |pages= 133–138 |year=2018 |doi= 10.1038/s41565-017-0023-9|arxiv=1801.00520 |bibcode=2018NatNa..13..133G }}</ref> This was attributed to a graphite-diamond transition, and the behavior appeared to be unique to bilayer graphene. This could have applications in personal armor.
== Porous nanoflakes ==
Hybridization processes change the intrinsic properties of graphene and/or induce poor interfaces. In 2014 a general route to obtain unstacked graphene via facile, templated, catalytic growth was announced. The resulting material has a specific surface area of 1628 m2 g-1, is [[electrical conductivity|electrically conductive]] and has a [[mesoporous]] structure.<ref name=rd1403>{{cite web|author=Tue, 03/04/2014 - 3:35pm |url=http://www.rdmag.com/news/2014/03/researchers-develop-intrinsically-unstacked-double-layer-graphene |title=Researchers develop intrinsically unstacked double-layer graphene |doi=10.1038/ncomms4410 |publisher=Rdmag.com |date= |accessdate=2014-04-05|bibcode = 2014NatCo...5E3410Z }}</ref>
The material is made with a mesoporous nanoflake template. Graphene layers are deposited onto the template. The carbon atoms accumulate in the mesopores, forming protuberances that act as spacers to prevent stacking. The protuberance density is approximately {{val|5.8|e=14|u=m-2}}. Graphene is deposited on both sides of the flakes.<ref name=rd1403/>
During CVD synthesis the protuberances produce intrinsically unstacked double-layer graphene after the removal of the nanoflakes. The presence of such protuberances on the surface can weaken the π-π interactions between graphene layers and thus reduce stacking. The bilayer graphene shows a specific surface area of {{val|1628|u=m2/g}}, a pore size ranging from 2 to 7 nm and a total pore volume of {{val|2.0|u= cm3/g}}.<ref name=rd1403/>
Using bilary graphene as cathode material for a [[lithium sulfur battery]] yielded reversible capacities of 1034 and 734 mA h/g at discharge rates of 5 and 10 C, respectively. After 1000 cycles reversible capacities of some 530 and 380 mA h/g were retained at 5 and 10 C, with [[coulombic efficiency]] constants at 96 and 98%, respectively.<ref name=rd1403/>
Electrical conductivity of 438 S/cm was obtained. Even after the infiltration of sulfur, electrical conductivity of 107 S cm/1 was retained. The graphene's unique porous structure allowed the effective storage of sulfur in the interlayer space, which gives rise to an efficient connection between the sulfur and graphene and prevents the diffusion of polysulfides into the [[electrolyte]].<ref name=rd1403/>
== Characterisation ==
[[Hyperspectral]] global [[Raman spectroscopy|Raman]] imaging<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Gaufrès|first1=E.|last2=Tang|first2=N. Y.-Wa|last3=Lapointe|first3=F.|last4=Cabana|first4=J.|last5=Nadon|first5=M.-A.|last6=Cottenye|first6=N.|last7=Raymond|first7=F.|last8=Szkopek|first8=T.|last9=Martel|first9=R.|title=Giant Raman scattering from J-aggregated dyes inside carbon nanotubes for multispectral imaging|journal=Nature Photonics|date=24 November 2013|doi=10.1038/NPHOTON.2013.309|bibcode = 2014NaPho...8...72G|volume=8|pages=72–78}}<!--|accessdate=8 April 2015--></ref> is an accurate and rapid technique to spatially characterize product quality. The vibrational modes of a system characterize it, providing information on [[stoichiometry]], composition, [[Morphology (linguistics)|morphology]], [[Stress (mechanics)|stress]] and number of layers. Monitoring graphene's G and D peaks (around 1580 and 1360 cm<sup>−1</sup>)<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Li|first1=Q.-Q.|last2=Zhang|first2=X.|last3=Han|first3=W.-P.|last4=Lu|first4=Y.|last5=Shi|first5=W.|last6=Wu|first6=J.-B.|last7=Tan|first7=P.-H.|title=Raman spectroscopy at the edges of multilayer graphene|journal=Carbon|date=27 December 2014|volume=85|pages=221–224|doi=10.1016/j.carbon.2014.12.096|arxiv=1412.8049}}<!--|accessdate=8 April 2015--></ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Wu|first1=Jiang-Bin|last2=Zhang|first2=Xin|last3=Ijäs|first3=Mari|last4=Han|first4=Wen-Peng|last5=Qiao|first5=Xiao-Fen|last6=Li|first6=Xiao-Li|last7=Jiang|first7=De-Sheng|last8=Ferrari|first8=Andrea C.|last9=Tan|first9=Ping-Heng|title=Resonant Raman spectroscopy of twisted multilayer graphene|journal=Nature Communications|date=10 November 2014|doi=10.1038/ncomms6309 |bibcode = 2014NatCo...5E5309W|volume=5|pages=5309|arxiv = 1408.6017 }}<!--|accessdate=8 April 2015--></ref> intensity gives direct information on the number of layers of the sample.

[[File:Double fold seen from the side.svg|thumbnail|How a double fold is made using a test piece (seen from the side).]] [[File:Double fold.svg|thumbnail|A double fold is made by first folding the test piece backwards and then forwards to its initial position (one complete oscillation).]] {{for|the book by Nicholson Baker|Double Fold}} A '''double fold''' is a process of folding a [[paper]] sample first backwards and then forwards about the same line, i.e. one complete oscillation. The number of double folds that is required to make a test piece break is used to determine the material's [[folding endurance]] and [[fold number]].
The total folding angle (about the folding line) differs depending on which folding tester is used, for instance the Köhler–Molin instrument folds about 156° on each side of the vertical line, resulting in a complete [[oscillation]] of about 2 × 312° for each double fold, while the [[MIT]] instrument employs a folding angle of about 135° on each side (that is, a complete oscillation of about 2 × 270° for each complete double fold).<ref>ISO 5626:1993 Paper – Determination of folding endurance, Annex A.</ref>
Strictly speaking, the first double fold is more than one complete oscillation since the flap needs to be folded from vertical to its starting position before the counting begins.
The process was analyzed and criticized by [[Nicholson Baker]] in his 2001 book ''[[Double Fold|Double Fold: Libraries and the Assault on Paper]]''.

{{Distinguish|Ecophenotype|Subspecies}}
[[Image:Ecotypes of Physcomitrella patens.JPG|thumb|200px|right|Four different [[ecotypes]] of ''[[Physcomitrella patens]]'', stored at the [[International Moss Stock Center]]]]
In [[evolutionary ecology]], an '''ecotype''',<ref group=note>Greek: ''οίκος'' = home and ''τύπος'' = type, coined by [[Göte Turesson]] in 1922</ref> sometimes called '''ecospecies''', describes a genetically distinct geographic variety, [[Population biology|population]] or [[Race (biology)|race]] within a [[species]], which is genotypically [[Adaptation|adapted]] to specific environmental conditions.
Typically, though ecotypes exhibit [[Phenotype|phenotypic]] differences (such as in [[Morphology (biology)|morphology]] or [[physiology]]) stemming from environmental heterogeneity, they are capable of interbreeding with other geographically adjacent ecotypes without loss of fertility or vigor. <ref name="BTH">''Ecology: From individuals to ecosystems'' by Begon, Townsend, Harper, Blackwell Publishing 4th ed. (2006), p.5,6,7,8</ref><ref name="G.">{{cite book | last =Turesson | first =Turesson G. | title =The genotypical response of the plant species to the habitat | publisher =Hereditas 3 | year =1922 | pages =211–350 }}</ref><ref name="Molles">{{cite book | last =Molles | first =Manuel C., Jr. | title =Ecology: Concepts and Applications | publisher =The McGraw-Hill Companies, Inc.| edition = 3rd | year =2005 | location =New York | pages =201 | isbn = 978-0-07-243969-4}}</ref><ref name="ee">''Environmental Encyclopedia'' by Bortman, Brimblecombe, Mary Ann Cunningham, William P. Cunningham, Freedman - 3rd ed., p.435, "Ecotype"</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://botanydictionary.org/ecotype.html|title=ecotype - Dictionary of botany|author=|date=|website=botanydictionary.org}}</ref>
==Definition== An ecotype is a variant in which the [[Phenotype|phenotypic]] differences are too few or too subtle to warrant being classified as a subspecies. These can occur in the same geographic region where distinct habitats such as meadow, forest, swamp, and sand dunes provide ecological niches. Where similar ecological conditions occur in widely separated places it is possible for a similar ecotype to occur. This is different than a subspecies, which may exist across a number of different habitats. In animals, ecotypes can be regarded as micro-subspecies that owe their differing characteristics to the effects of a very local environment.<ref>{{cite book|author=Ernst Mayr|title=Systematics and the Origin of Species, from the Viewpoint of a Zoologist|publisher=Harvard University Press|year=1999|chapter=VIII-Nongeographic speciation|pages=194–195|url=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=mAIjnLp6r_MC&pg=PA194|isbn=9780674862500}}</ref> Therefore, ecotypes have no [[taxonomic rank]].
==Terminology== {{Refimprove section|date=December 2016}} Ecotypes are closely related to [[Polymorphism (biology)|morphs]]. In the context of [[evolutionary biology]], [[Polymorphism (biology)|genetic polymorphism]] is the occurrence in the equilibrium of two or more distinctly different phenotypes within a population of a species, in other words, the occurrence of more than one '''form''' or '''morph'''. The frequency of these discontinuous forms (even that of the rarest) is too high to be explained by [[mutation]]. In order to be classified as such, morphs must occupy the same habitat at the same time and belong to a [[panmictic]] population (whose all members can potentially interbreed). Polymorphism is actively and steadily maintained in populations of species by natural selection (most famously [[sexual dimorphism]] in humans) in contrast to ''transient polymorphisms'' where conditions in a habitat change in such a way that a "form" is being replaced completely by another.
In fact, Begon, Townsend, and Harper assert that
{{Cquote|''There is not always clear distinction between local ecotypes and genetic polymorphisms.''}}
The notions "form" and "ecotype" may appear to correspond to a static phenomenon, however; this is not always the case. Evolution occurs continuously both in time and space, so that two ecotypes or forms may qualify as distinct species in only a few generations. Begon, Townsend, and Harper use an illuminating analogy on this:
{{Cquote|''… the origin of a species, whether [[Allopatric speciation|allopatric]] or [[Sympatric speciation|sympatric]], is a process, not an event. For the formation of a new species, like the boiling of an egg, there is some freedom to argue about when it is completed.''}}
Thus ecotypes and morphs can be thought of as precursory steps of potential [[speciation]].
==Range and distribution== Experiments indicate that sometimes ecotypes manifest only when separated by great spatial distances (of the order of 1,000 km). This is due to [[hybrid (biology)|hybridization]] whereby different but adjacent varieties of the same species (or generally of the same [[taxonomic rank]]) interbreed, thus overcoming local selection. However other studies reveal that the opposite may happen, i.e., ecotypes revealing at very small scales (of the order of 10 m), within populations, and despite hybridization.<ref name="BTH" />
In ecotypes, it is common for continuous, gradual geographic variation to impose analogous phenotypic and genetic variation.<ref name="BTH" /> This situation is called [[Cline (biology)|cline]]. A well-known example of a cline is the skin color gradation in indigenous human populations worldwide, which is related to latitude and amounts of sunlight.<ref>"Race". (2009). ''Encyclopædia Britannica''. Ultimate Reference Suite. Chicago: Encyclopædia Britannica.</ref> But often the distribution of ecotypes is [[Bimodal distribution|bimodal]] or multimodal. This means that ecotypes may display two or more distinct and discontinuous phenotypes even within the same population. Such phenomenon may lead to [[speciation]] and can occur if conditions in a local environment change dramatically through space or time.<ref name="BTH" />
==Examples== [[File:Caribou.jpg|thumb|[[Migratory woodland caribou|''Rangifer tarandus caribou'']], a member of the woodland ecotype.]]
* [[Earthworms]] fall into four different ecotypes. Compost earthworms prefer warm and moist environments with a ready supply of fresh compost material. [[Epigeic]] earthworms live on the surface of the soil in [[leaf litter]] and tend not to make burrows but live in and feed on the leaf litter. Endogeic earthworms live in and feed on the soil, making horizontal burrows through the soil to move around and to feed and they will reuse these burrows to a certain extent. Anecic earthworms make permanent vertical burrows in soil, feeding on leaves on the soil surface that they drag into their burrows.<ref name="test">[http://www.earthwormsoc.org.uk/earthworm-information/earthworm-information-page-2 Earthworm ecotypes], information from the Earthworm Society of Britain about the different ecotypes of British earthworms.</ref> * [[Tundra]] reindeer and woodland reindeer are two ecotypes of [[reindeer]]. The first migrate (travelling 5,000 km) annually between the two environments in large numbers whereas the other (who are much fewer) remain in the forest for the summer.<ref>"reindeer (Rangifer tarandus)" Encyclopædia Britannica. Ultimate Reference Suite. Chicago: Encyclopædia Britannica, 2009</ref> In North America, the species ''Rangifer tarandus'' (locally known as caribou,<ref name=COSEWIC /><ref name=COSEWIC>{{citation|title=Designatable Units for Caribou (Rangifer tarandus) in Canada |url=http://www.cosewic.gc.ca/eng/sct12/COSEWIC_Caribou_DU_Report_23Dec2011.pdf |format=PDF |work=COSEWIC |year=2011 |institution=Committee on the Status of Endangered Wildlife in Canada |location=Ottawa, Ontario |pages=88 |accessdate=18 December 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303234528/http://www.cosewic.gc.ca/eng/sct12/COSEWIC_Caribou_DU_Report_23Dec2011.pdf |archivedate=3 March 2016 |df= }}</ref><ref>COSEWIC 2011:3.</ref> was subdivided into five subspecies<ref group=note>Banfield, who worked with both the [[Canadian Wildlife Service]] and the [[National Museum of Canada]], in his often-cited 1961 classification, identified five subspecies of ''Rangifer tarandus:'' 1) the largely migratory [[barren-ground caribou]] subspecies ''Rangifer tarandus groenlandicus,'' which are found mainly in the [[Canada|Canadian]] territories of [[Nunavut]] and the Northwest Territories, along with western [[Greenland]]; 2) the subspecies ''Rangifer tarandus caribou'' which is divided into ecotypes: [[boreal woodland caribou]], (also known as forest-dwelling, woodland caribou (boreal), mountain woodland caribou and [[migratory woodland caribou]]) —the migratory George River Caribou Herd, for example in the Ungava region of Quebec; 3) Rangifer tarandus pearyi ([[Peary caribou]]), the smallest of the species, known as Tuktu in Inuktitut, found in the northern islands of [[Nunavut]] and the Northwest Territories; 4) ''Rangifer tarandus granti'' subspecies [[Porcupine caribou|Grant’s caribou]], which are mainly migratory and live in Alaska and the northern Yukon and 5) the ''R. t. dawsoni'' subspecies; † [[Queen Charlotte Islands caribou]] from the [[Haida Gwaii|Queen Charlotte Islands]] (extinct since 1910)</ref> by Banfield in 1961.<ref name=Banfield_1961>{{citation|last=Banfield|first=Alexander William Francis|year=1961|title=A Revision of the Reindeer and Caribou, Genus Rangifer| institution=[[National Museum of Canada]] |journal=Bulletin|volume=177|series=Biological Services|number=66}}</ref><ref>[[Reindeer]]</ref> Caribou are classified by ecotype depending on several behavioural factors – predominant habitat use (northern, tundra, mountain, forest, boreal forest, forest-dwelling), spacing (dispersed or aggregated) and migration (sedentary or migratory).<ref>{{citation|last=Bergerud|first=Arthur T.|year=1996 |title=Evolving Perspectives on Caribou Population Dynamics, Have We Got it Right Yet?|journal=Rangifer|volume=Special Issue|number=9|pages=59–115}}</ref><ref>{{citation|last1=Festa-Bianchet|first1=M.|last2=Ray|first2=J.C.|last3=Boutin|first3=S.|last4=Côté|first4=S.D.|last5=Gunn|first5=A.|year=2011|title=Conservation of Caribou (Rangifer tarandus) in Canada: An Uncertain Future|journal=Canadian Journal of Zoology|volume=89|issue=5|pages=419–434|doi=10.1139/z11-025|display-authors=etal}}</ref><ref>{{citation|title=Population Structure and Hybridization of Alaskan Caribou and Reindeer: Integrating Genetics and Local Knowledge|first=Karen H.|last=Mager|type=PhD dissertation|url=http://www.uaf.edu/files/rap/Mager_16apr2012_Dissertation-1.pdf|format=PDF|accessdate=27 December 2013|institution=e University of Alaska Fairbanks|location=Fairbanks, Alaska|year=2012}}</ref> For example, the subspecies ''Rangifer tarandus caribou'' is further distinguished by a number of ecotypes, including [[boreal woodland caribou]], mountain woodland caribou and [[migratory woodland caribou]])—the migratory George River Caribou Herd, for example in the Ungava region of Quebec. * [[Arabis|''Arabis fecunda'']], a herb [[Endemism|endemic]] to some [[calcareous]] soils of Montana, United States, can be divided into two ecotypes. The one "low elevation" group lives near the ground in an arid, warm environment and has thus developed a significantly greater tolerance against drought than the "high elevation" group. The two ecotypes are separated by a horizontal distance of about 100 km.<ref name="BTH" /> * It is commonly accepted that the [[Tucuxi]] dolphin has two ecotypes – the riverine ecotype found in some South American rivers and the pelagic ecotype found in the South Atlantic Ocean.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.springerlink.com/content/w01617k562021220/|title=Riverine and marine ecotypes of Sotalia dolphins are different species | doi=10.1007/s00227-005-0078-2 | volume=148|issue=2 |journal=Marine Biology|pages=449–457|year=2005 |last1=Cunha |first1=H.A |last2=Da Silva |first2=V.M.F |last3=Lailson-Brito |first3=J |last4=Santos |first4=M.C.O |last5=Flores |first5=P.A.C |last6=Martin |first6=A.R |last7=Azevedo |first7=A.F |last8=Fragoso |first8=A.B.L |last9=Zanelatto |first9=R.C |last10=Solé-Cava |first10=A.M }}</ref> Similarly, it is accepted that the [[common bottlenose dolphin]] has two ecotypes in the western North Atlantic.<ref>[[Common bottlenose dolphin]]</ref> * The [[warbler finch]] and the [[Cocos Island finch]] are viewed as separate ecotypes.<ref>''Encyclopedia of life sciences'', 2007, John Wiley & Sons, "Darwin's Finches"</ref>{{check|date=May 2012}}{{clarify|date=May 2012}}<!-- these are different species, probably not even congeneric --> * The [[Scots pine]] (''Pinus sylvestris'') has 20 different ecotypes in an area from Scotland to Siberia, all capable of interbreeding.<ref>''Introduction to Ecology (1983)'', J.C. Emberlin, chapter 8</ref> * A very subtle case of ecotype is the following: It has been observed that two populations of the same ''[[Helix (gastropod)|Helix]]'' snail species separated by only a few hundred kilometers prefer not to cross-mate, i.e. they reject one another as mates. This event probably occurs during the process of courtship, which may last for hours.

{{EngvarB|date=March 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2014}} [[File:Electric power transmission line towards the south-east in the Tsavo East National Park, Kenya 2.jpg|thumb|300px|Electricity Transmission in Kenya.]] '''Energy in Kenya''' describes [[World energy resources and consumption|energy]] and [[Electricity generation|electricity]] production, consumption, import and export in Kenya. Kenya's current effective installed (grid connected) electricity capacity is 2,351 MW, with peak demand of 1,802 MW, as at June 2018.<ref name="1R">{{cite web|title=Electricity demand crosses 1,800 MW mark |access-date=3 July 2018 |first=Neville |last=Otuki | newspaper=[[Business Daily Africa]] |date=3 July 2018 | url=https://www.businessdailyafrica.com/economy/Electricity-demand--crosses-1-800MW-mark/3946234-4645308-ur8eup/index.html| location=Nairobi}}</ref> At that time, demand was rising at a calculated rate of 3.6 percent annually, given that peak demand was 1,770 MW, at the beginning of 2018.<ref name="1R"/> Electricity supply is predominantly sourced from hydro and fossil fuel (thermal) sources.<ref name="2R">{{cite web|author=GENI | url=http://www.geni.org/globalenergy/library/national_energy_grid/kenya/index.shtml |title=National Energy Grid Kenya | publisher=[[Global Energy Network Institute]] (GENI) | location=San Diego |date=20 June 2016 |access-date=3 July 2018}}</ref>
Just until recently the country lacked significant domestic reserves of [[fossil fuel]]. The country has over the years had to import substantial amounts of [[crude oil]] and natural gas. This might change with the discovery of oil reserves in Kenya, which relied on oil imports to meet about 42 percent of its energy needs in 2010. As of the end of June 2016, 55% of Kenyans were connected to the National grid, which is one of the highest connection rates in Sub-Saharan Africa.<ref name="3R">{{cite web |url=https://qz.com/882938/kenya-is-rolling-out-its-national-electricity-program-in-half-the-time-it-took-america/ | title=Kenya’s national electrification campaign is taking less than half the time it took America |access-date=3 July 2018 | date=16 January 2017 |author=Lily Kuo |publisher=Quartz Africa | location=New York City}}</ref> Per capita consumption in domestic households however, remains low.<ref name="1R"/>
==Electricity== [[File:Worker in Olkaria Kenya.jpg|thumb|250px|Worker at [[Olkaria II Geothermal Power Plant|Olkaria Geothermal Plant]].]]
===Sources of electricity=== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="margin: 0.5em auto" |+ Generation Capacity of Electricity in Kenya<ref name="4R">{{cite web |publisher=Energypedia.info |author=Energypedia | url=https://energypedia.info/wiki/Kenya_Energy_Situation | title=Kenya Energy Situation |access-date=3 July 2018 |date=5 June 2018}}</ref><ref name="5R">{{cite web|access-date=3 June 2018 | url=https://www.globallegalinsights.com/practice-areas/energy-laws-and-regulations/kenya |title=Energy in Kenya 2018 | publisher=Globallegalinsights.com | author=Global Legal Insights}}</ref> ! Source (as June 2018) || Capacity (MW) || Capacity % |- |Hydro ||<center>705 ||<center>30.0% |- |Fossil Fuels (incl. gas, diesel and emergency power) ||<center> 306 ||<center> 13.0% |- |Geothermal ||<center>1,105 ||<center> 47.0% |- |[[Bagasse]] Cogeneration ||<center> 42 ||<center> 1.8% |- |Wind ||<center> 10.0 ||<center> 0.4% |- |Others||<center>183.0 ||<center> 7.8% |- !Total ||<center> 2,351 ||<center> 100.0% |}
{| class="wikitable sortable" style="margin: 0.5em auto" |+ Generation Sources of Electricity in Kenya<ref name="6R">{{cite web|title=Kenya: Electricity and Heat for 2015 | url=https://www.iea.org/statistics/statisticssearch/report/?country=Kenya&product=electricityandheat |access-date=3 July 2018 |date=31 December 2015 |publisher=[[International Energy Agency]] (IEA) |author=International Energy Agency |location=Paris}}</ref> ! Source (2015) || Generation (GWh) || Share % |- |Hydro || 3,310 || 36% |- |Oil || 1,714 || 19% |- |Geothermal || 4479 || 44% |- | Biofuels || 136 || 1% |- |Wind || 38|| <1% |- |Solar || 1|| <1% |- !Total || 9,258 || 100% |}
===Renewable energy=== {{Main article|Renewable energy in Kenya|Geothermal power in Kenya|Wind power in Kenya}} Kenya is currently the largest producer of geothermal energy in Africa. It is one of two countries in Africa that produce geothermal energy, the other being Ethiopia. In 2010, geothermal accounted for almost 20 percent of Kenya's total electricity generation. The country has the potential to produce 10,000 megawatts of geothermal-powered electricity, according to Kenya's state-owned Geothermal Development Company.<ref name="7R">{{cite web|url=https://www.eia.gov/beta/international/country.php?iso=KEN |title=Kenya's Key Energy Statistics |publisher=Eia.gov | date=30 May 2013 |access-date=3 July 2018 |author=U.S. Energy Information Administration |location=Washington, DC}}</ref> Total renewable energy capacity is at 60%, with most of that coming from Hydro-Power.<ref name="8R">{{cite web|date=18 June 2012 | url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130613001823/http://www.iaea.org/nuclearenergy/nuclearknowledge/schools/NEM-school/2012/Japan/PDFs/week2/CR6_Kenya.pdf |format=Archived from the Original |title=Kenya’s Energy Demand and the role of Nuclear energy in future energy generation mix |access-date=4 July 2018 |publisher=[[International Atomic Energy Agency]] (IAEA) | author=Catherine Kathambi Kianji |location=Vienna}}</ref>
===Hydroelectric power=== {{Main article|Hydroelectric power in Kenya}}
===Utilities=== In Kenya, there are plans by the [[government of Kenya]], to end the monopoly of the electricity distribution market; but until that happens, power distribution is only held by one company; [[Kenya Power and Lighting Company]] (Kenya Power).<ref name="9R">{{cite news|title=House seeks to end Kenya Power's monopoly |url=https://www.businessdailyafrica.com/House-seeks-to-end-Kenya-Power-monopoly/-/539546/1910994/-/3d10fs/-/index.html | date=10 July 2013 |access-date=4 July 2018 |first=Edwin | last=Mutai |newspaper=[[Business Daily Africa]] | location=Nairobi}}</ref>
However, [[Kenya Electricity Generating Company]] (KenGen), is responsible for generating approximately 90% of installed capacity. Independent Power Producers (IPPs) are responsible for about 10% of installed capacity. The following IPPs are active in Kenya: (a) Westmont (b) AEP Energy Africa (Iberafrica)<ref name="10R">{{cite web|url=https://www.nation.co.ke/business/SA-firm-buys-out-Moi-era-power-producer-Iberafrica/996-4637426-fi1srk/index.html |title=SA firm buys out Moi-era power producer Iberafrica |date=29 June 2018 |access-date=4 July 2018 | newspaper=[[Daily Nation]] |first=Geoffrey |last=Irungu | location=Nairobi}}</ref> (c) OrPower4 Kenya Limited (a subsidiary of [[Ormat Technologies]]) (d) Tsavo Power Company (e) Aggreko (f) Africa Geothermal International<ref name="11R">{{cite web| url=https://www.businessdailyafrica.com/Corporate-News/US-based-firm-joins-steam-power-production-in-Kenya/-/539550/1742762/-/9hbwx3z/-/index.html |title=US-based firm joins steam power production in Kenya |date=8 April 2013 |access-date=4 July 2018 |newspaper=[[Business Daily Africa]] | first=David |last=Herbling |location=Nairobi}}</ref>
===Consumption=== The biggest consumer of electricity in Kenya is [[Kenya Pipeline Company]], followed by [[Bamburi Cement]].<ref name="12R">{{cite web|title=Why Bamburi cement put off mega plans for alternative solar energy |access-date=4 July 2018 |date=18 December 2017 | url=https://www.standardmedia.co.ke/business/article/2001263429/why-bamburi-cement-put-off-mega-plans-for-alternative-solar-energy |last=Kajilwa |first=Graham |newspaper=[[The Standard (Kenya)]] |location=Nairobi}}</ref> As of July 2018, of the 6.5 million Kenya Power's customers, 5 percent or 348,459, were commercial customers (including businesses and factories). Of these, the largest 6,000, were responsible for 60 percent of the national power consumption, averaging in excess of 15,000 electricity units per month.<ref name="1R"/>
==Petroleum==
===Imports=== Kenya had one of the largest crude oil refineries in East Africa, the 90,000-barrels-per-day (bbl/d) Mombasa refinery. The refinery typically operated below capacity and processed Murban heavy crude from Abu Dhabi and other heavy Middle-Eastern crude grades. The refinery was shut down in February 2016.<ref name="13R">{{cite web|url=https://www.nation.co.ke/business/Refinery-to-become-storage-facility/996-3086224-x1xk2cz/index.html | title=Refinery plant to be used a storage facility |date=21 February 2016 |access-date=4 July 2018 |first=Immaculate | last=Karambu |newspaper=[[Daily Nation]] |location=Nairobi}}</ref>
In 2011, Kenya imported about 33,000 bbl/d of crude oil entirely from the United Arab Emirates, according to the Kenya National Bureau of Statistics (KNBS). Kenya imported 51,000 bbl/d of refined oil products in 2011, according to KNBS. Kenya has a product pipeline system that transports petroleum products from Mombasa to inland areas.<ref name="14R">{{cite news| url=https://www.capitalfm.co.ke/business/2015/07/kenya-pipeline-signs-financing-for-sh35bn-mombasa-nairobi-line/ |title=Kenya Pipeline signs financing for Sh35 billion Mombasa-Nairobi Line | date=15 July 2015 |access-date=4 July 2018 |location=Nairobi | publisher=[[98.4 Capital FM]] |author=Capital News}}</ref>
In 2017, Kenya consumed {{convert|2480000000|liter|0}}, of [[diesel fuel]]. The same year, the country used {{convert|1672800000|liter|0}}, of refined [[gasoline|petrol]].<ref name="15R">{{cite web|date=9 October 2017 |access-date=4 July 2018 |url=https://www.nation.co.ke/business/Diesel-consumption-drops-time-in-7-years/996-4131012-dbhnaa/index.html |title=Diesel consumption drops for first time in 7 years |newspaper=[[Daily Nation]] |first=Neville |last=Otuki |location=Nairobi}}</ref>
===Reserves=== In 2012 oil was discovered in Kenya. As of May 2016, proven reserves were estimated at 766 million barrels. This puts Kenya ahead of [[Uzbekistan]] in the global rankings. [[Tullow Oil]], one of the companies prospecting for oil in the country, is of the opinion that the national reserves are in excess of 1 billion barrels.<ref name="16R">{{cite web|url=https://qz.com/681250/kenya-may-have-a-lot-more-oil-than-it-previously-thought/ |title=Kenya may have a lot more oil than it previously thought |author=Lily Kuo |date=11 May 2016 |publisher=[[Quartz Africa]] |location=New York City |access-date=4 July 2018}}</ref>
===Production=== After the collapse of negotiations to build the [[Uganda-Kenya Crude Oil Pipeline]], Kenya began to make plans to build the {{convert|554|mi|km}} [[Kenya Crude Oil Pipeline]] on its own.<ref name="17R">{{cite news|publisher=[[British Broadcasting Corporation]] (BBC) |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-36121081 |title=Uganda picks Tanzania for oil pipeline, drops Kenya plan |access-date=4 July 2018 |date=23 April 2016 | author=BBC News}}</ref><ref name="18R">{{cite news |first=George |url=http://www.businessdailyafrica.com/Opinion-and-Analysis/Fast-track-Turkana-Lamu-pipeline-/-/539548/3177856/-/item/0/-/ahd6cjz/-/index.html | title=Fast track Turkana-Lamu pipeline to beat Uganda to global oil markets |access-date=4 July 2018 |date=26 April 2016 | last=Wachira|newspaper=[[Business Daily Africa]] | location=Nairobi}}</ref>
==Challenges== Fuelwood demand in the country is 3.5 million tonnes per year while its supply is 1.5 million tonnes per year. The massive deficit in fuelwood supply has led to high rates of deforestation in both exotic and indigenous vegetation resulting in adverse environmental effects such as desertification, [[land degradation]], droughts and famine.<ref name="19R">{{cite web| url=https://af.reuters.com/article/topNews/idAFKBN1I41C7-OZATP | title=Corrupt officials to blame for loss of Kenya’s forest cover: government report |access-date=4 July 2018 |date=3 May 2018 | publisher=[[Reuters|Reuters Africa]] |first=John |last=Ndiso | location=Johannesburg}}</ref>
==Future== ==Electricity== [[File:Worker in Olkaria Kenya.jpg|thumb|250px|Worker at [[Olkaria II Geothermal Power Plant|Olkaria Geothermal Plant]].]]
===Sources of electricity=== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="margin: 0.5em auto" |+ Projected Generation Capacity and Demand of Electricity in Kenya<ref name="1R"/> ! Year || Demand|| Capacity |- |2013|| 1,191 MW || 1,600 MW |- |2018|| 1,802<ref name="1R"/> || 2,351 MW<ref name="1R"/> |- |2030|| 15,000 MW || 19,200 MW |}
===Projected generation mix===
{| class="sortable wikitable" |- ! Source || Capacity (MW) || Capacity % |- |Geothermal || 5,530 || 26% |- |Nuclear|| 4,000 || 19% |- |Coal|| 2,720 || 13% |- |GT-NG || 2,340 || 11% |- |MSD|| 1,955|| 9% |- |Imports || 2,000 || 9% |- |Wind|| 2,036 || 9% |- |Hydro|| 1,039 || 5% |- |Total|| 21,620 || 100% |} {{smaller|* Source: International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)}}
===Eastern Africa Power Pool (EAPP)=== Seven countries came together because they saw mutual benefit in having one power pool. The original countries were:<ref name="20R">{{cite web|location=Washington, DC |author=World Bank |url=http://www.worldbank.org/projects/P126579/regional-eastern-africa-power-pool-project-apl1?lang=en |title=Projects: The Eastern Electricity Highway Project under the First Phase of the Eastern Africa Power Integration Program |publisher=[[World Bank]]}}</ref> (a) Burundi (b) Democratic Republic of the Congo (c) Egypt (d) Ethiopia (e) Kenya (f) Rwanda and (g) Sudan.<ref name="20R"/>
Later, more countries joined the pool, including:<ref name="21R">{{cite web|url=http://eappool.org/ | title=About The Eastern Africa Power Pool |access-date=4 July 2018 |date=2016 |publisher=The Eastern Africa Power Pool (EAPP) |author=EAPP |location=Addis Ababa}}</ref> (a) Tanzania (b) Libya (c) Djibouti and (d) Uganda.<ref name="21R"/>
The objective of the Eastern Africa Power Pool (EAPP) is to increase the volume and reduce the cost of electricity supply in Kenya; and to provide revenues to Ethiopia through the export of electricity from Ethiopia to Kenya.<ref name="21R"/> The process of connecting the Ethiopian grid to the Kenyan grid is underway.<ref name="22R">{{cite web|url=https://www.the-star.co.ke/news/2017/08/02/power-line-to-reduce-costs-by-seven-shillings_c1607695 |title=Power line to reduce costs by seven shillings |date=2 August 2017 |access-date=4 July 2018 | newspaper=[[The Star (Kenya)]] | first=Abel |last=Muhaita | location=Nairobi}}</ref>
Kenya also plans to be connected to the South African grid, through Tanzania, Zambia and Zimbabwe. That process is also underway as of July 2018.<ref name="23R">{{cite web| url=http://www.theeastafrican.co.ke/business/Kenya+to+link+to+SA+power+grid+by+2015+/-/2560/1477184/-/eri8mp/-/index.html | title=Kenya to link to Southern African power grid by 2015 | date=11 August 2012 |access-date=4 July 2018 |location=Nairobi |newspaper=[[The EastAfrican]] |author=Staff Reporter}}</ref><ref name="24R">{{cite web|access-date=4 July 2018 |format=PDF | url=http://www.afdb.org/fileadmin/uploads/afdb/Documents/Environmental-and-Social-Assessments/Kenya-Tanzania_-_Power_Interconnection_Project_-_ESIA_Summary.pdf |date=July 2014 |publisher=[[African Development Bank]] | title=Multinational Kenya–Tanzania Power Interconnection Project: Country : Kenya and Tanzania: Project Number : P-Z1- FA0-052 | author=Asfaw S; Kulemeka N et al.| location=Abidjan}}</ref>
===Geothermal power=== Geothermal power plants, which convert steam generated from hot rocks deep underground into electricity, have a prominent place in Kenya’s overarching development plans. These include the Vision 2030, the NCCAP, and the current ‘5000+ MW in 40 months initiative’. Geothermal power has the potential to provide reliable, cost-competitive, baseload power with a small carbon footprint, and reduces vulnerability to climate by diversifying power supply away from hydropower, which currently provides the majority of Kenya’s electricity. Kenya has set out ambitious targets for geothermal energy. It aims to expand its geothermal power production capacity to 5,000 MW by 2030, with a medium-term target of installing 1,887 MW by 2017. As of October 2014, Kenya has an installed geothermal capacity of approximately 340 MW. Although there is significant political will and ambition, reaching these ambitions is a major challenge.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://cdkn.org/resource/nama-geothermal-power-lessons-kenya/?loclang=en_gb|title=INSIDE STORY: Nationally Appropriate Mitigation Action (NAMA) to accelerate geothermal power: Lessons from Kenya - Climate and Development Knowledge Network|work=Climate and Development Knowledge Network|access-date=2017-08-23|language=en-US}}</ref> [[Kenya Electricity Generating Company| Kenya Electricity Generating Company (KenGen)]] and Geothermal Development Company aim at raising the country's geothermal output from the current 593MW, to 1 GW by the year 2018<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.theeastafrican.co.ke/news/Kenya-in-cheaper-geothermal-option--/-/2558/1471406/-/6osd6j/-/index.html|title=Kenya in cheaper geothermal option|work=The East African|access-date=2017-08-23|language=en-UK}}</ref> and 5 GW to the grid by 2030.<ref>{{cite web|author=Organised by |url=http://www.african-utility-week.com/Pages/Detail/6359 |title=Kenya targets 5,000 MW of geothermal power by 2030 |publisher=African-utility-week.com }}</ref>
===Nuclear power=== {{Main article|Nuclear energy in Kenya}} In 2017, the Kenya Nuclear Electrification Board (Kneb) estimated that a 1,000 MW nuclear plant could be operational by 2027 and cost Ksh500-600 billion ($5-$6 billion).<ref>{{cite web|title=Kenya plans nuclear plant by 2027|url=http://www.theeastafrican.co.ke/business/Kenya-plans-to-set-up-nuclear-plant-by-2027/2560-4215876-14gd00jz/index.html |website=The East African|accessdate=26 December 2017|language=en-UK|date=5 December 2017}}</ref> In September 2010 Former Energy and Petroleum Ministry PS Patrick Nyoike<ref>{{cite web |title=Office of public communications:Partick Nyoike |url=http://www.communication.go.ke/ministry.asp?personid=77 |accessdate=16 September 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100921165128/http://communication.go.ke/ministry.asp?personid=77 |archivedate=21 September 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> announced, that Kenya aims to build a 1,000 MW [[Nuclear power|nuclear power plant]] between 2017–2022.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.ngrguardiannews.com/business-news/81424-kenya-to-commission-first-nuclear-plant-in-2022-|title=Kenya to commission first nuclear plant in 2022|date=2013-08-06|work=archive.is |access-date=2017-08-23|deadurl=yes|archiveurl= https://archive.is/20130806030856/http://www.ngrguardiannews.com/business-news/81424-kenya-to-commission-first-nuclear-plant-in-2022- |archivedate=6 August 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref> For Kenya to achieve middle-income status, Nyoike viewed nuclear energy as the best way to produce safe, clean, reliable and base load (constant supply) electricity. The projected cost using South Korean technology was US$3.5 billion.<ref name="bloomberg"> {{cite web | url = https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2010-09-20/kenya-aims-to-build-a-nuclear-power-plant-by-2017-minister-nyoike-says.html | title = Kenya Aims to Build a Nuclear Power Plant by 2017 | date= 20 September 2010 | publisher = [[Bloomberg L.P.]] | accessdate=5 June 2011}} </ref>
==Carbon emissions== Kenya emits .03 percent of the world carbon dioxide, which is about 12.62 (Million Metric Tons of CO₂).<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.juancole.com/2013/05/funding-africas-largest.html |title=Kenya gets Funding for Africa's Largest Wind Farm | Informed Comment |publisher=Juancole.com |date=16 May 2013}}</ref>

{{more citations needed|date=January 2018}} [[Electric power system]]s consist of generation plants of different energy sources, transmission networks, and distribution lines. Each of these components can have environmental impacts at multiple stages of their development and use including in their construction, during the [[Electricity generation|generation of electricity]], and in their decommissioning and disposal. We can split these impacts into operational impacts (fuel sourcing, global atmospheric and localized pollution) and construction impacts (manufacturing, installation, decommissioning, and disposal). This page looks exclusively at the operational '''environmental impact of electricity generation'''. The page is organized by energy source and includes impacts such as water usage, emissions, local pollution, and wildlife displacement. More detailed information on electricity generation impacts for specific technologies and on other environmental impacts of electric power systems in general can be found under the [[:Category:Environmental impact of the energy industry]]. ==Water usage== Water usage is one of the most obvious environmental impacts of electricity generation. All thermal cycles (coal, natural gas, nuclear, geothermal, and biomass) use water as a cooling fluid to drive the [[thermodynamic cycle]]s that allow electricity to be extracted from heat energy. Other energy sources such as wind and solar use water for cleaning equipment, while hydroelectricity has water usage from evaporation from the reservoirs. The amount of water usage is often of great concern for electricity generating systems as populations increase and droughts become a concern. In addition, changes in water resources may impact the reliability of electricity generation.A Review of Operational Water Consumption and Withdrawal Factors for Electricity Generating Technologies. NREL Technical Report NREL/TP-6A20-50900. March 2011. By Jordan Macknick, Robin Newmark, Garvin Heath, and KC Hallett. https://www.nrel.gov/docs/fy11osti/50900.pdf The power sector in the United States withdraws more water than any other sector and is heavily dependent on available water resources. According to the [[U.S. Geological Survey]], in 2005, thermo-electric power generation water withdrawals accounted for 41 percent (201 Bgal/d) of all freshwater withdrawals. Nearly all of the water withdrawn for thermoelectric power was surface water used for once-through cooling at power plants. Withdrawals for [[irrigation]] and public supply in 2005 were 37% and 13% of all freshwater withdrawals respectively.Kenny, J.F.; Barber, N.L.; Hutson, S.S.; Linsey, K.S.; Lovelace, J.K.; Maupin, M.A. ''Estimated Use of Water in the United States in 2005''. U.S. Geological Survey Circular 1344. Reston, VA: USGS, 2009; p. 52. https://pubs.usgs.gov/circ/1344/ Likely future trends in water consumption are covered here.AAAS Annual Meeting 17–21 February 2011, Washington DC. Sustainable or Not? Impacts and Uncertainties of Low-Carbon Energy Technologies on Water. Dr Evangelos Tzimas, European Commission, JRC Institute for Energy, Petten, Netherlands Discussions of water usage of electricity generation distinguish between water withdrawal and water consumption. According to the [[United States Geological Survey|USGS]], “withdrawal” is defined as the amount of water removed from the ground or diverted from a water source for use, while “consumption” refers to the amount of water that is evaporated, transpired, incorporated into products or crops, or otherwise removed from the immediate water environment. Both water withdrawal and consumption are important environmental impacts to evaluate. General numbers for fresh water usage of different power sources are shown below. {| class="wikitable" |- !   ! colspan="3" | Water Consumption (gal/MW-h) |- ! Power source ! Low case ! Medium/average case ! High case |- | [[Nuclear power]] | 100 (once-through cooling) | 270 once-through, 650 (tower and pond) | 845 (cooling tower) |- | [[Coal]] | 58 {{cite web|title=Majuba Power Station|url=http://www.eskom.co.za/Whatweredoing/ElectricityGeneration/PowerStations/Pages/Majuba_Power_Station.aspx|accessdate=2 March 2015}} |500 | 1,100 (cooling tower, generic combustion) |- | [[Natural gas]] | 100 (once-through cycle) |800 (steam-cycle, cooling towers) | 1,170 (steam-cycle with cooling towers) |- | [[Hydroelectricity]] |1,430 |4,491 |18,000 |- | [[Solar thermal]] |53 (dry cooling){{Cite book|title=Renewable and efficient electric power systems|last=Masters|first=Gilbert M|publisher=Wiley-Interscience|year=2004|isbn=|location=Hoboken, N.J.|pages=}} |800 |1,060 (Trough) |- | [[Geothermal]] | 1,800 | | 4,000 |- | [[Biomass]] | 300 | | 480 |- | Solar [[photovoltaic]] |0 |26 |33 |- | [[Wind power]] | 0 | 0 | 1 |} Steam-cycle plants (nuclear, coal, NG, solar thermal) require a great deal of water for cooling, to remove the heat at the steam condensers. The amount of water needed relative to plant output will be reduced with increasing [[boiler]] temperatures. Coal- and gas-fired boilers can produce high steam temperatures and so are more efficient, and require less cooling water relative to output. Nuclear boilers are limited in steam temperature by material constraints, and solar is limited by concentration of the energy source. Thermal cycle plants near the ocean have the option of using [[seawater]]. Such a site will not have cooling towers and will be much less limited by environmental concerns of the discharge temperature since dumping heat will have very little effect on water temperatures. This will also not deplete the water available for other uses. [[Nuclear power in Japan]] for instance, uses no cooling towers at all because all plants are located on the coast. If dry cooling systems are used, significant water from the water table will not be used. Other, more novel, cooling solutions exist, such as sewage cooling at the [[Palo Verde Nuclear Generating Station]]. Hydroelectricity's main cause of water usage is both evaporation and seepage into the water table. Reference: [[Nuclear Energy Institute]] [http://www.nei.org/filefolder/water_consumption__npps_Nov_2007.pdf factsheet]{{dead link|date=September 2015}} using EPRI data and other sources. {| style="font-size:95%; text-align:right;" class="wikitable sortable" |+ '''Electricity industry (incl. gas & liquid fuels) value chain - water consumption,{{cite journal|author1=World Economic Forum |author2=Cambridge Energy Research Associates |date=1 February 2009 |title=Thirsty Energy: Water and Energy in the 21st Century |url=http://www2.cera.com/docs/WEF_Fall2008_CERA.pdf |format=PDF |accessdate=1 November 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110708132727/http://www2.cera.com/docs/WEF_Fall2008_CERA.pdf |archivedate=8 July 2011 }} [[Life cycle assessment|LCA]] [[emission intensity]] & [[capacity factor]]''' |- !
